meanings.definition: To cause (something) to fall into disrepair or ruin.
meanings.sent1: The neglect of the old house will dilapidate it over time.
meanings.sent2: Leaving a car unused for years can dilapidate its engine.
meanings.sent3: The lack of maintenance will dilapidate the playground equipment, making it unsafe for children.
meanings.sent4: The storm's strong winds seemed to dilapidate the fragile structure in minutes.
meanings.sent5: The constant exposure to harsh weather will slowly dilapidate the wooden fence.

meanings.definition: To fall into disrepair or ruin.
meanings.sent1: If we don't fix the leaky roof, the entire house will dilapidate.
meanings.sent2: Over time, the neglected building started to dilapidate.
meanings.sent3: The once beautiful garden began to dilapidate, much to the dismay of the owner.
meanings.sent4: The abandoned factory continued to dilapidate, a sad reminder of its former glory.
meanings.sent5: The lack of care caused the antique furniture to dilapidate rapidly.
